close_symbols: lfs_file_t (definition: members pos, flags, ctz (head,size), cache, block)
lfs_t (definition: at least member rcache and rcache.block)
explanation:
To decide whether the loops in lfs_file_flush violate the MISRA for-loop well-formedness rule you must know which objects are acting as loop counters or loop-control flags and whether any functions called inside the loop bodies modify those objects (the MISRA rule treats the effect of called functions as part of the loop body). The following symbols are therefore required:

- lfs_file_t (members pos, flags, ctz, cache, block): file->pos and file->ctz.size are the loop-condition objects (while (file->pos < file->ctz.size)). You must know their exact types and whether they can be modified by called functions.

- lfs_ctz_t / ctz struct (head, size): ctz.size appears in the loop condition; its semantics and whether it can be changed by called routines must be known.

- lfs_t (at least rcache and rcache.block): lfs->rcache is touched inside the loop and its block field is tested (rcache.block != LFS_BLOCK_NULL). You must know whether functions update rcache (affecting subsequent iterations).

- lfs_file_flushedread: called in the loop body; must know its side effects (does it modify file positions, ctz, cache, or other objects used in the loop condition?).

- lfs_file_flushedwrite: called in the loop body; must know if it modifies file->pos, file->ctz.size, file->cache, or other objects used in the loop condition (this is the most likely function to advance the loop counter).

- lfs_cache_drop: called inside the loop; must know whether it has side effects on cache objects that influence loop-control objects (e.g. rcache or file->cache) or subsequent behavior of the loop.

- lfs_bd_flush: used in the subsequent while(true) loop; its side effects (including calls it makes) may modify file fields tested by outer/other loops or affect control flow (it may return LFS_ERR_CORRUPT to trigger relocation).

- lfs_file_relocate: invoked from the bd_flush error path; must know whether it modifies file->pos, file->ctz, file->block, or other loop-condition objects (it is jumped to from inside a loop, so its side effects count toward the loop body behaviour).

- LFS_BLOCK_NULL: constant tested against rcache.block; include to understand the rcache check semantics and whether that condition depends on values changed in the loop body.

- LFS_ERR_CORRUPT: bd_flush's error comparison; needed to determine control flow (whether an error leads to relocation and thus to lfs_file_relocate side effects inside the loop).

- lfs_max: used in the inline-writing branch (file->pos = lfs_max(...)). While not inside the while loops, include to confirm it has no hidden side effects (MISRA requires verifying called functions inside loop bodies — lfs_max helps verify no side effects elsewhere in the function).

In short: include all functions called from within the loop bodies and the concrete definitions of the structures/fields used in the loop conditions so you can determine whether any loop-control objects are modified directly or indirectly by the loop body (including via called functions).
